narrative: Yeah, I was in the boy scouts at the time. And we was doing the 50-yard dash, racing, but we was at the pier, marked off and so we was doing the 50-yard dash. There was about 8 or 9 of us, you know, going down, coming back. And going down the third time, I caught cramps and I started yelling "Help!", but the fellows didn't believe me, you know. They thought I was just trying to catch up, because I was going on or slowing down. So all of them kept going. They leave me. And so I started going down. Scoutmaster was up there. He was watching me. But he didn't pay me no attention either. And for no reason at all there was another guy, who had just walked up that minute... He just jumped over and grabbed me.

lures.1.5: We were all eager, full of energy, ready to prove ourselves.
lures.2.5: The sun was setting, casting long shadows on the wooden planks.
lures.3.5: The air was filled with the salty scent of the sea and the distant cries of seagulls.
lures.4.5: The cool breeze from the ocean was a welcome relief from the summer heat.
lures.5.5: Our scoutmaster, a stern man with a gruff voice, was overseeing the race.
lures.6.5: We were all competitive, each wanting to be the fastest, the strongest.
lures.7.5: I was always a good swimmer, but the sudden cramp took me by surprise.
lures.8.5: My voice echoed off the water, swallowed by the sound of the waves.
lures.9.5: Their laughter echoed in my ears, a cruel reminder of their disbelief.
lures.10.5: My legs felt like lead, the water pulling me down with an unrelenting force.
lures.11.5: Their laughter faded, replaced by the deafening silence of my solitude.
lures.12.5: The water was cold, a stark contrast to the warm summer evening.
lures.13.5: The water was up to my neck, then my chin, and then I was under.
lures.14.5: He was too far away, too engrossed in his conversation with another scout.
lures.15.5: His eyes were on me, but his mind was elsewhere.
lures.16.5: His indifference was a cold slap, a harsh reality I was forced to face.
lures.17.5: He was a stranger, a passerby, someone who had no reason to care.
lures.18.5: Without a moment's hesitation, he leapt into the water.
lures.19.5: His grip was firm, pulling me back to the surface, back to safety.
